snippet: From Mitt Romney’s perspective, the time was ripe to cast the president as someone who apologizes for America.
abstract: Deadly attack on American diplomatic post in Libya propels foreign policy to forefront of presidential campaign and presents an unexpected test not only to Pres Obama, who must manage an international crisis, but also to Mitt Romney; Romney accuses Obama of apologizing for American values, but comes under criticism for distorting the chain of events overseas and appearing to seek political advantage from the attack.

byline.original: By PETER BAKER and ASHLEY PARKER
byline.contributor: Peter Baker reported from Washington, and Ashley Parker from Jacksonville, Fla. David E. Sanger, Jonathan Weisman and John H. Cushman Jr. contributed reporting from Washington, and Michael Barbaro and David W. Chen from New York.

lead_paragraph: From Mitt Romney’s perspective, the time was ripe to cast the president as someone who apologizes for America.
